titlestmt.titleproper: Preliminary Inventory of the Andrew Nagorski interview recordings
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Hoover Institution Archives Staff

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-27T16:05-0700
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: Donor inventory and name index input into AT by Sarah Patton.

did.abstract: Interviews of political leaders, dissidents and others, mainly relating to political and social conditions in Poland, other countries of Eastern Europe, and post-Soviet Russia.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

The Hoover Institution Archives only allows access to copies of audiovisual items, computer media, and digital files. To listen to sound recordings or to view videos, films, or digital files during your visit, please contact the Archives at least two working days before your arrival. We will then advise you of the accessibility of the material you wish to see or hear. Please note that not all material is immediately accessible.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Andrew Nagorski interview recordings, [Tape no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2017.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: American journalist; Newsweek foreign correspondent and editor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Interviews of political leaders, dissidents and others, mainly relating to political and social conditions in Poland, other countries of Eastern Europe, and post-Soviet Russia. Many of the interviews from the late 1980s and early 1990s were used not only for Newsweek stories but also for Nagorski's book, The Birth of Freedom (1993).

did.unittitle: Gdańsk Lenin Shipyard, Wałęsa and Mazowiecki,
On campaign trail in Mielec and Rzeszów,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Extended interview with Bujak while he was still leading the Solidarity underground movement and in hiding. Circumstances of the interview are described in Nagorski's book, The Birth of Freedom.

did.unittitle: Visit to UN in New York,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On set during filming of Schindler’s List in Krakow with Spielberg, Liam Neesen, Ben Kingsley, and Nusia Horowitz (sister of Ryszard Horowitz, both actual members of Schindler’s List, the two children featured in the film and who appear at the end of the film with the other survivors). Nagorski's story about the filming ran in Newsweek.

did.unittitle: Andrzej Wajda, Bronisław Geremek, Zbigniew Bujak,
Andrzej Celiński (side A and part of B) and Aleksander Kwaśniewski (side B),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interview conducted in Moldova while he was still in charge of Russian forces there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interview for article that ran in Newsweek International, September 25, 1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In his Prague apartment during dissident days.

did.unittitle: Jan Čarnogurský (Slovakia, side A) and Václav Mály (side B),
Gyula Horn, László Békesi, Gábor Jeszensky, Péter Boross,

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Joint interview with Newsweek editor Maynard Parker. Interview caused an uproar because of Kohl’s comparison of Gorbachev’s PR technique to Joseph Goebbels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Should include the story of his wife who had informed on him for the Stasi. Nagorski wrote an article about this that appeared in the June 23, 1997 issue of Newsweek.

did.unittitle: Klaus and Eva Klein (Berlin Wall escapees),
Warren Zimmermann (head of US delegation to OSCE),
Karl Schlögel (German writer on concept of Mitteleuropa),
Alan Paton (anti-apartheid activist, Durban, South Africa),

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brief testimonial for Polish edition of Newsweek.

did.unittitle: Radio Interviews about Soviet Union and Eastern Europe
Radio show, Nagorski’s expulsion from Soviet Union,
